awd_titl_txt: Impact of Ethnic Studies Courses on the sense of belonging, professional identity, self-efficacy and retention of underrepresented students in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
The project combines a research project aimed at broadening participation in STEM with a detailed professional development plan focused on facilitating the principal investigator's transition from a subject-specific focus on the cellular and network mechanisms of experience-dependent plasticity to a focus on STEM education research. The research project and professional development plan will launch a long-term research program focused on combining quantitative and qualitative approaches to increase recruitment and retention of underrepresented minorities in STEM. This will be achieved through the development of interventions rooted in robust multivariate statistical methods and a deep understanding of the challenges and barriers these students face, examined through a theoretical lens that combines student-asset models, neurobiology pf learning and memory and critical race theory. The professional development plan includes developing research design skills through focused collaborations, attending quantitative and qualitative research methods summer workshops, auditing/taking courses on qualitative research methods and Critical Race Theory frameworks, and attending conferences that focus on these last two areas as they apply to STEM education research.  The outcome of the professional development plan is to enable the principal investigator to complete an innovative research study and develop expertise that will allow her to make significant contributions to the field of STEM education

The research will apply a mixed methods approach to assess the relationship between taking Chicano Studies courses and underrepresented minority (URM) students' sense of belonging, science identity, and self-efficacy, as well as their likelihood to persist in STEM majors until graduation. To achieve this goal, the investigator will complete three objectives: (1) Assess the relationship between taking Chicano Studies courses on the sense of belonging, self-efficacy, and science identity of URM STEM students; (2) Evaluate the impact of taking Chicano Studies courses on the sense of belonging, self-efficacy and science identity of URM students in STEM; and (3) Characterize the reasons why URM students choose to take Chicano Studies courses and the overall impact of these courses on students' experiences. The investigator's long-term research plan focuses on improving outcomes for students of all backgrounds and experiences who are interested in developing careers in STEM. The long-term research agenda includes documenting and characterizing the experiences of STEM students along the academic pathway; identifying, developing, and assessing affordable, scalable, interventions that can have significant impacts on their experiences; and exploring the intersection of biological knowledge and learning with students' cultures.

The project is supported through the EHR Core Research: Building Capacity in STEM Education Research (ECR:BCSER) competition that is designed to build individuals' capacity to carry out high quality fundamental STEM education research in STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many of the challenges faced by humanity in the 21st century are technological/scientific in nature. To identify solutions, we need diverse scientists that can approach these problems from a variety of perspectives and disciplines. Despite decades of efforts aimed at diversifying the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) workforce, the current composition fails to represent the diversity of the US population. This mismatch is not due to differences in interest in STEM degrees across different student populations, but instead reflects the disproportionate attrition of students of color, first generation students and low income students from STEM during their first years in college. One of the main reasons for this attrition is a lack of representation, support and community within their disciplines. Ethnic Studies courses have been found consistently to empower and increase engagement of students of color in K-12, which suggested that these courses could serve as an intervention to foster a sense of belonging, promote agency and create community between students of color in Higher Education; a hypothesis that remained untested. Such an outcome could be used by universities and policymakers to guide the development of programs and educational curricula that either include Ethnic Studies as required courses in STEM majors or that incorporate elements of Ethnic Studies disciplines into existing STEM courses, as a strategy to increase retention of students of color in STEM. 

In this study, we evaluated the impact of participating in Ethnic Studies on the sense of belonging and science identity of STEM students in a large, public, minority-serving university. Students were asked to complete surveys before and after completing a Chicano Studies course and a subset were also interviewed about their experiences with the course and how it related to their commitment to their STEM major. Across the board, students found that taking the Chicano Studies course improved their understanding of the experiences and culture of Latinx/Chicanx students. For students who didn't identify as Latinx/Chicanx, they discussed developing empathy and an appreciation of the struggles faced by their fellow students, while for those who identified as Latinx/Chicanx, they reported an increase in their ethnic identity as well as their understanding of their own community. Furthermore, Latinx/Chicanx students reported finding a strong community of peers that helped them find their place in the university and develop a strong sense of belonging to the institution. Many students discussed their experiences in the Chicano Studies course as a source of strength and support to continue within their majors, particularly for STEM majors who felt displaced in their own STEM disciplines. When discussing what aspects of the Chicano Studies course were most valuable to the students, they emphasized feeling that their opinion was valued and respected as well as being able to make connections between their lives and the content of the course. They also appreciated seeing faculty and teaching assistants that looked like them as well as not being one of the only students of color in their classroom. These statements are consistent with prior literature that shows that many students of color find the content of STEM courses to be very abstract and unrelated to their daily lives and long-term goals, factors that contribute to the attrition of students of color from STEM. 

These findings suggest that the impact of Ethnic Studies courses on students' engagement and sense of belonging is not limited to K-12 environments, but continues through Higher Education. In addition, they highlight specific aspects of Ethnic Studies courses that were valuable for students of color that could easily be incorporated into STEM courses, with the potential to promote community and retention of these students in STEM. Furthermore, our findings support our initial hypothesis that Ethnic Studies courses contribute to increased sense of belonging and community building in university students, highlighting the importance of these courses in supporting the success of students of color in Higher Education.
